abstract.text: Read series data from condensed workouts.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To reduce the size of workout data, HealthKit can condense samples associated with workouts created on Apple Watch. HealthKit enumerates the data associated with a workout and adds that data to one or more quantity series samples. After saving all the data to series objects, HealthKit deletes the originals. In addition, it converts older
HealthKit only condenses high-frequency data recorded by the Workout app on Apple Watch. This includes the following data types:
For these data types, HealthKit condenses samples that are more than 90 days old and associated with a workout that’s at least 5 minutes long.

HealthKit may condense samples for a given workout more than once. For example, if the system syncs new samples associated with the workout to the device, or if the condenser algorithm changes, HealthKit may condense the workout again.

HealthKit also batches the data into multiple quantity series to optimize how the system lays out the data in memory. For many data types, HealthKit creates a separate quantity series for each 5-minute interval in the workout. The condensation process preserves all the data from the original workout — but it greatly reduces the overhead needed to save that data to disk. However, your app may need to perform additional steps to read the condensed data.

content.text: Query high-frequency data from a condensed workout

inlineContent.text: Because HealthKit condenses older workout data, any samples associated with a workout may actually represent a series of higher-frequency data. In many cases, you can just use these samples, without having to access the underlying data. For example,
transparently operate on the underlying data.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
A sample that represents a cumulative quantity.
A sample that represents a discrete quantity.
A sample that represents a quantity, including the value and the units.
The number of quantities contained in this sample.
A query that accesses the series data associated with a quantity sample.
A quantity sample type that measures the amount of active energy the user has burned.
A quantity sample type that measures the resting energy burned by the user.
A quantity sample type that measures the distance the user has moved by cycling.
A quantity sample type that measures the distance the user has moved by walking or running.
A quantity sample type that measures the user’s heart rate.
A query that performs multiple statistics queries over a series of fixed-length time intervals.
A query that performs statistical calculations over a set of matching quantity samples, and returns the results.
A workout sample that stores information about a single physical activity.
An object that describes an activity within a longer workout.
The type of activity performed during a workout.
A builder object that incrementally constructs a workout.
An object representing an important event during a workout.
The type of session.
A type that identifies samples that store information about a workout.
The workout type identifier.
Create associated samples that add details to a workout.
Partition multisport and interval workouts into activities that represent the different parts of the workout.

abstract.text: Manage workouts, workout sessions, and activity summaries.
